name: Clin T
title: Clinical T
notes:
**Note 1:** Periosteum is a fibrous membrane that wraps the outer surface of bones. Cortical bone is the dense compact outer layer of the bone. Trabecular, cancellous, or spongy bone (spongiosa) is a porous network of tissue filling the interior of bone, decreasing weight and allowing room for blood vessels and marrow.

**Note 2:** For the following descriptions, assign the appropriate T category based on the tumor size when involvement is limited to the cortical bone. Involvement through cortical bone is required for assignment of T4a. 

    Invasive tumor on one side confined to:
        Lamina propria
        Submucosa
    
    Adjacent oral cavity
    Bone, NOS
    Cortical bone of mandible
    Cortical bone of maxilla
    Cortical bone, NOS
    Inferior surface of soft palate
    Lateral pharyngeal wall
    Lingual surface of epiglottis
    Mandible, NOS
    Maxilla, NOS
    Musculature invaded
    Oropharynx
    Vallecula

    Localized, NOS
rows:
(lip) Tumor invades through cortical bone, inferior alveolar
nerver, floor of mouth, or skin (chin or nodes)

(oral cavity) Tumor invades through cortical bone, into
deep/extrinsic muscle of tongue (genioglossus, hypoglossus,
palatoglossu, and styloglossus), maxillary sinus, or skin of
face

Deep (extrinsic) muscle of tongue: 
    Genioglossus 
    Hyoglossus 
    Palatoglossus 
    Styloglossus

Maxillary antrum (sinus)
Nasal cavity
Skin of face/neck
Tongue

Trabecular bone:
    Mandible
    Maxilla
    Palatine bone

Stated as T4a

(lip and oral cavity) Tumor invades masticator space, 
pterygoid plates, or skull base, or encases internal carotid
artery

Specified bone 

Masticator space
Pterygoid plates

Further contiguous extension: 
   Skull base
   Internal carotid artery (encased)

Stated as T4b

Unknown; extension not stated
Not documented in patient record
Tumor 2 cm or less in greatest dimension

Tumor more than 2 cm but not more than 4 cm in greatest
dimension
Tumor more than 4 cm in greatest dimension
